item.title: Star Wars Jedi Character is Making his TV Debut Next Month
item.content:encoded:
Star Wars Jedi’s Cal Kestis is finally making his way out of the game and coming to a TV screen near you on September 19.

The Star Wars Jedi series is one of the most popular game franchises, and players have fallen in love with the main character, Cal Kestis. However, Kestis has only appeared in video games for quite some time and has not made any appearances in other Star Wars properties. That is about to change, as his television debut has finally been announced.

LEGO Star Wars: Rebuild the Galaxy is Finally Bringing Cal Kestis Outside of the Games

Spotted by Gamesradar+, the details about Cal Kestis’ TV debut come from a new blog post on starwars.com. The blog post is for a four-part sequel series, LEGO Star Wars: Rebuild the Galaxy – Pieces of the Past. Although no details about the character’s role in the series have been revealed, it is known that Cameron Monaghan will return to portray the titular character. The cast of the upcoming sequel appears to be stacked. Check out everyone who is involved below:

LEGO Star Wars: Rebuild the Galaxy – Pieces of the Past Cast Revealed

  • Billy Dee Williams as Lando
  • Alan Tudyk as K-2SO
  • Ben Schwartz as Jaxxon
  • Dan Stevens as Solitus
  • Gaten Matarazzo as Sig Greebling
  • Tony Revolori as Dev Greebling
  • Bobby Moynihan as Jedi Bob
  • Marsai Martin as Yesi
  • Michael Cusack as Servo
  • Ahmed Best as Darth Jar Jar
  • Anthony Daniels as C-3PO
  • Sam Witwer as Maul
  • Helen Sadler as Darth Rey
  • Phil LaMarr as Darth Kit Fisto
  • Matthew Wood as General Grievous
  • Jake Green as Greedo
  • Shelby Young as Princess Leia
  • Piotr Michael as Yoda
  • Matt Sloan as Jedi Vader
  • Trevor Devall as Jedi Master Sheev
  • Dee Bradley Baker as Darth Nubs
  • Naomi Ackie as Jedi Jannah
  • Kevin Michael Richardson as Jedi Jabba the Hutt
  • Kelly Marie Tran as Darth Rose Tico
  • Ashley Eckstein as Ahsoka Tano
  • Catherine Taber as Pirate Queen Amidala
  • Cameron Monaghan as Cal Kestis
  • Nika Futterman as Asajj Ventress
  • Andre Sogliuzzo as Cassian Andor
  • James Arnold Taylor as Obi-Wan Kenobi
  • Brian George as Ki-Adi-Mundi.
  • Special Guest Appearance by Mark Hamill

In other news, Star Wars Outlaws is coming to the Nintendo Switch 2 in September. Additionally, a sequel to Outlaws was canceled “very, very early.” What are your thoughts on Cal Kestis making his TV debut and the absolutely stacked cast of LEGO Star Wars: Rebuild the Galaxy – Pieces of the Past? Let us know through the official Insider Gaming forums discussion.

For more information from Insider Gaming, read about Nintendo updating its detachable dual-screen patent. Don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

Nintendo’s detachable dual-screen patent has received an update yesterday, introducing new images and more.

GTA 5 Devs Scrapped a Climbing Feature, Dataminer Reveals

GTA 5 would have had a feature that allowed players to climb poles, pipes and walls; but it was ultimately scrapped.

Resident Evil Requiem Will Have 3 Playable Characters, It’s Claimed

According to a leaker, Resident Evil Requiem features three playable characters, two of which have yet to be seen in action.

item.title: Nintendo’s Detachable Dual-Screen Patent Has Been Updated
item.content:encoded:
Nintendo has recently updated its detachable dual-screen patent.

Nintendo and patents are two words that we have been listening to together constantly for the past couple of months, however, not for the reasons you would expect. The patents in question relate to the Palworld lawsuit, with Nintendo recently modifying one of them. However, the new update is for a hardware tech, rather than a game.

Is Nintendo Going to Announce a Detachable Second Screen for the Switch 2?

Spotted by Gameranx, Mike Odyssey on X (formerly Twitter) informed players about the update on Nintendo’s detachable dual-screen patent. Their post reveals that the update was released yesterday, August 14, 2025, accompanied by new images. These images illustrate how the detachable screen connects to the primary device and also showcase the spring mechanism and various buttons that will be used on the device.

For those wondering, the patent regarding Nintendo’s detachable second screen was seen first in 2023. At that time, many players speculated that Nintendo could be returning to its roots with the Switch 2, introducing a DS-like second screen that could be detached when not in use. However, the Switch 2 has now been released, and we have yet to see any announcements for this detachable screen.

In other news, a new claim states that Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 will not be available on the Nintendo Switch 2 at launch. Additionally, a Palworld lookalike has been spotted on Nintendo’s store. What are your thoughts on Nintendo updating its detachable dual-screen patent? Let us know through the official Insider Gaming forums discussion.

item.title: GTA 5 Devs Scrapped a Climbing Feature, Dataminer Reveals
item.content:encoded:
A dataminer has uncovered that GTA 5 had a climbing feature that was tested and scrapped before launch.

Players have been eagerly awaiting more GTA 6 news since the game’s release date was announced, set for May 26, 2026. However, all we have learned since the last trailer is that the upcoming title will feature a “fair price“. However, until we see some gameplay for GTA 6, players can read about new details on GTA 5’s scrapped features that have surfaced online.

GTA 5 Had a Feature Called ‘Handholds’, Which Was Tested and Scrapped

Spotted by Gamerant, the new details about GTA 5’s cancelled climbing feature come from Lucas7yoshi_RS on X (formerly Twitter). It seems that developers were testing a feature called “Handholds,” which was used to define “climbable” objects in the game. These included pipes, walls, poles, and more. The dataminer found a file called “handholds.xml”, but the file only contains test points.

The dataminer also points out a recent video from GTA content creator, whatever57010, which highlights “some oddly placed lightpoles”. The dataminer notes that several test points were also discovered near the same roof as the light poles. Moreover, the poles might have been there to test the climbing features; however, the GTA 5 developer may have forgotten to remove them afterward. Interested readers can check out these test points in the post embedded below:

GTA 5 NPC Behaviour Detailed in Game Files

While scouring through the files, the dataminer also found references to NPC behaviour in GTA 5. For example, homeless NPCs would insult and ask for change from Michael and Franklin, but would only greet Trevor with a simple ‘hi’. Similarly, buff NPCs would insult Michael, calling him unfit, whereas Franklin would get a ‘hi’ from them. Moreover, firemen, medics, and posh NPCs only say hi to Michael.

In other news, GTA’s longest-serving actor doubts he will be a part of GTA 6. Also, GTA Online will soon require age verification to play, according to a new claim. What are your thoughts on GTA 5 developers testing and scrapping the climbing feature? Do you think the feature can be included in GTA 6? Let us know through the official Insider Gaming forums discussion.
